original: Bohlin, Anders Birger, lektor, Halmstad, f. 26/3/98 i Lidköp. av rektor Gust. B. o. Brita Kumlin. G. 27 m. Ellen Staffansson. Barn: Sven-Staffan f. 36. — Stud:ex. i Strängnäs 16, fil. mag. i Upps. 22, fil. lic.^ 26, fil. dr 35. Docent i paleontologi 34-44, lektor i biol. m. hälsolära o. kemi v. h. a. 1. i Halmstad sed. 44. Stud:res. t. olika europ. länder o. t. USA, t. Kina 27-33 s. medarb. i utgrävn. v. Chow-K’ou-Tien o. s. medl. av Sven Hedins exp. t. Centralasien. Skr.: ett 30-tal vet:skapL avh. o. art. i fack-tiidskr. rör. fossila ryggradsdjur, bl. a. Die Familie Giraffidae (akad. avh. 26), The fossil mammals from the Tertiary deposit of Taben buluk, West. Kansu (I 42 o. H 46), På jakt efter urmänn. förfäder (reseskiildr. 44). RNO.
translated: Bohlin, Anders Birger, teacher, Halmstad, born March 26th, 1898 in Lidköping. Son of principal Gust. B. and Brita Kumlin. Married in 1927 to Ellen Staffansson and they had one child, Sven-Staffan, born in 1936. Bohlin graduated from Strängnäs in 1916, earned his Bachelor's degree in Uppsala in 1922, his Master's degree in 1926, and his PhD in 1935, all in the field of paleontology. He was a docent in paleontology from 1934-1944 and then became a teacher in biology, health science, and chemistry at Halmstad starting in 1944. Bohlin traveled to various European countries, the US, and China between 1927-1933. He assisted in excavations in Chow-K'ou-Tien and was a member of Sven Hedin's expedition to Central Asia. Bohlin has written around 30 scientific articles about fossil vertebrates, including Die Familie Giraffidae (thesis, 1926), The fossil mammals from the Tertiary deposit of Taben buluk, West. Kansu (1942 and 1946), and På jakt efter urmänn. förfäder (travelogue, 1944). He was awarded the Royal Order of the North Star.

structured.name: Anders Birger Bohlin
jobTitle: Teacher in Biology, Health Science, and Chemistry

award.name: Royal Order of the North Star

structured.description: Anders Birger Bohlin was a Swedish teacher and paleontologist born in 1898 in Lidköping. He graduated from Strängnäs in 1916 and from Uppsala University with a Bachelor's degree in 1922, a Master's degree in 1926, and a PhD in 1935, all in the field of paleontology. Between 1934-1944, he was a docent in paleontology and later became a teacher in biology, health science, and chemistry at Halmstad starting in 1944. Bohlin traveled to various European countries, the US, and China between 1927-1933 and assisted in excavations in Chow-K'ou-Tien. He authored around 30 scientific articles about fossil vertebrates and was awarded the Royal Order of the North Star.
